natural problem: What is the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $9n-2$ and $7n + 3$ share a common factor greater than $1$?
natural solution: &= \text{gcd}\,(-41,n+18). \end{align}Since $41$ is prime, it follows that $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ have a common factor greater than 1 only if $n+18$ is divisible by 41. The smallest such positive integer value of $n$ is $41-18=\boxed{23}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and f g :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = 9 * n - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. g n = 7 * n + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> m. 1 < m \<longrightarrow> \<exists> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> m dvd (f n) \<and> m dvd (g n)"
shows  "23 = (LEAST n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> (\<exists> m. 1 < m \<and> m dvd (f n) \<and> m dvd (g n)))"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $9n-2$ and $7n + 3$ share a common factor greater than $1$? The final Answer is 23
 ### Proof
 By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align} \text{gcd}\,(9n-2,7n+3) &= \text{gcd}\,(9n-2-(7n+3),7n+3) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,7n+3) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,7n+3-3(2n-5)) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,n+18) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5-2(n+18),n+18) \\
 &= \text{gcd}\,(-41,n+18). \end{align}Since $41$ is prime, it follows that $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ have a common factor greater than 1 only if $n+18$ is divisible by 41. The smallest such positive integer value of $n$ is $41-18=\boxed{23}$.
 Note that $9n-2 = 205 = 5 \times 41$ and $7n+3 = 164 = 4 \times 41$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and f g :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = 9 * n - 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. g n = 7 * n + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> m. 1 < m \<longrightarrow> \<exists> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> m dvd (f n) \<and> m dvd (g n)"
shows  "23 = (LEAST n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> (\<exists> m. 1 < m \<and> m dvd (f n) \<and> m dvd (g n)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider two functions $f(n) = 9n - 2$ and $g(n) = 7n + 3$. Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that there exists an integer $m > 1$ that divides both $f(n)$ and $g(n)$. The final answer is 23.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "\<exists> d > 1. 9*n - 2 mod d = 0"
and h1 : "\<exists> d > 1. 7*n + 3 mod d = 0"
and h2 : "n > 0"
shows  "LEAST n. \<exists> d > 1. 9*n - 2 mod d = 0 \<and> 7*n + 3 mod d = 0 = 23"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $9n-2$ and $7n + 3$ share a common factor greater than $1$? The final Answer is 23
 ### Proof
 By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align} \text{gcd}\,(9n-2,7n+3) &= \text{gcd}\,(9n-2-(7n+3),7n+3) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,7n+3) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,7n+3-3(2n-5)) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5,n+18) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(2n-5-2(n+18),n+18) \\
 &= \text{gcd}\,(-41,n+18). \end{align}Since $41$ is prime, it follows that $9n-2$ and $7n+3$ have a common factor greater than 1 only if $n+18$ is divisible by 41. The smallest such positive integer value of $n$ is $41-18=\boxed{23}$.
 Note that $9n-2 = 205 = 5 \times 41$ and $7n+3 = 164 = 4 \times 41$.
 *)
